body.p: Goal: Show how to get started with a Dashboard layout in your apps.
Prerequisites: CSS Code Style, Asset Library
Step 1: To start using layouts you should install assets library and add necessary css files for your app.
The dashboard.html head should have the following content:
body.source:
<!DOCTYPE html> <html> <head> <title>Your App Name</title>
<meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge,chrome=1"> <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, minimum-scale=1.0, maximum-scale=1.0, user-scalable=no"> <meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-capable" content="yes"> <meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-status-bar-style" content="black">
<!-- Brand Assets styles --> <link href="../css/systemBar.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/> <link href="../css/_assetsDev.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/>
<!-- App specific styles --> <link href="css/dashboard.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css"/> </head>
body.p: The four meta tags are needed to make this web-page working correctly on other devices like mobiles, tablets etc. The two lines referring to the Brand Assets are also needed. App specific styles are needed for responsive design. Developers can change settings for @media queries depending on their app.
The dashboard.html body has the following content:

body.p: Here we have separation for two blocks: #TopMenu and #Container. The #TopMenu block has the System Bar inside. The #Container block has the app layout inside.
All class names which start with eaMyApp should be changed to your app name. Developers take care of the class names in their apps.
Step 2: Get styles from dashboard.less and change them to what you need in your app.
First three style blocks (.ebContextMenu, #TopMenu, #Container) are used only for demo purposes. In the real app they are not needed.
The .eaMyApp should be change to your app name. Others styles could be changed as necessary for your app.
Result: You should get an app with the Dashboard layout which can be modified for your needs.
